Expectation1: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation1: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with severe, life-threatening symptoms of an unknown illness.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The ER was chaos as the patient was wheeled in, gasping for breath, skin mottled and clammy. As a doctor, I was expected to diagnose quickly, to save lives with precision. I scanned the monitors, ordered labs, and tried to piece together the puzzle of his symptoms—nothing fit, and every second mattered. Suddenly, the building alarms blared, echoing through the halls. The hospital’s PA system announced a flash-flood warning; water was already rising outside. As a citizen, I knew I was supposed to help ensure everyone’s safety, to follow emergency protocols, maybe even help evacuate others. But my patient’s life hung in the balance, and abandoning him felt unthinkable. My mind raced, torn between my oath to heal and my duty to the community. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding action, each with consequences I couldn’t ignore.
